p: Anthropogenic climate change is the biggest threat to health in the 21st century and has the potential to disrupt planetary systems as we know them [1,2,3,4,5,6,7]. Adolescents are particularly vulnerable to the negative effects of the accelerating climate crisis [8,9], particularly in terms of negative mental health effects [10,11,12]. Anxiety concerning the consequences of climate change is widespread among adolescents and impacts their daily functioning [13]. Moreover, a recent review highlighted that climate change places adolescents at risk of further adverse mental health outcomes, including post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, sleep disorders and substance abuse [10].
